answer: She is, Mom. She's the most perfect girl in the whole world.

question: I remember when your father picked me up for our first date. I swear he was the most handsome man that I had ever laid eyes on. I knew right then and there that this would be the man that I married.
answer: I hope that happens tonight.

question: It will, Ronnie. Then you'll have to give her a ring like the one your father gave me.
answer: Is that a yellow diamond?

question: It's a glass diamond. This is how it looks now.
answer: Mom, why did Dad leave?

question: Well, he kind of freaked out when you were born. You had so many special needs that he just couldn't handle the pressure. One day, he just couldn't take it anymore.
answer: Do you think it was my fault that Dad left?

question: Definitely. You don't think it was mine do you?
answer: Well, I didn't know, with the drinking and all.

question: Nope, it was all you. I love you, Ronnie.
answer: I love you, too, Mom. Damn, that was pretty impressive.

question: I love you, too, Mom. Damn, that was pretty impressive.
answer: Yeah, work's been pissing me off, so I just need to blow off some steam.

question: Well, Brandi, can I just say that you look absolutely beautiful tonight.
answer: Yeah, I know. Nurse! Get me another -- You got this, right?

question: Yeah, yeah. No problem.
answer: Nurse! Bring me another and keep 'em coming. I think it's funny to call the waitress nurse. Hey, what's that?

question: Oh, it's nothing.
answer: Don't be stingy, what the fuck is that?

question: It's just a pill I'm supposed to take.
answer: Let me see. Where the fuck did you find these?

question: The Doctor.
answer: Damn, Ronnie, Klonopin. I'm impressed. This is the good shit. I didn't know you partied like this.

question: Yeah, I guess I party like this every four to six hours as needed.
answer: Let me get one.

question: Help yourself.
answer: Hell yeah!

question: So, how do you like working at the mall?
answer: I hate that shit. All I do is listen to bitching all day long. I got to put makeup on these fat- ass women all day and it's like, I don't give a shit what you do, you can't polish a turd.

question: Yeah, I see how that could get to you.
answer: Let's do some shots. Waiter, four shots of Jager!

question: That's a lot.
answer: It's Friday.

question: So, Brandi, I hope I'm not being too forward, but do you have a boyfriend?
answer: I've got a few hook-ups but nobody who is a boyfriend.

question: Yes!
answer: You know, it's just like a time in my life where I want to be free right now and think about myself. Not get tied down to one person.

question: Yeah, I understand. I hate ties. I recently cut mine and now I'm free like a bird.
answer: Alright, bottoms up.

question: To new beginnings.
answer: Right up your ass!

question: Okay.
answer: Oh, shit!

question: No more. I'm sticking to beer.
answer: What's wrong, is your pussy hurting?

question: God, you remind me so much of my mother.
answer: Feel the burn, bitch!

question: You are so beautiful.
answer: Who wants to see my titties?!

question: Brandi, this is the most fun I've ever had on a date.
answer: For the last time, this ain't a date, motherfucker! This is a party!

question: Wooo! Um, so, Brandi, it's no secret that I'm attracted to you. I think everybody in the mall is. As you know, I recently split with my girlfriend and basically, I was wondering if, since you don't have a boyfriend, that I could maybe be your boyfriend and you could be my girlfriend?
answer: That's my house!

question: Brandi, I had a wonderful time tonight.
answer: I'm so fucking shit-faced.

question: Are you okay?
answer: My breath smells like asshole.

question: I love you, Brandi.
answer: I think I've got puke in my teeth.

question: Excuse me.
answer: How may I help you?

question: I need to talk to you.
answer: What is it, honey? Let me guess. You're looking for something to take care of those blackheads and hide that puffiness under your eyes. I've got just the thing.

question: No, that's not it. Well, how much is it?
answer: Fifty dollars for the bottle.

question: Okay, I'll take it. Listen, I know you're Ronnie's new girlfriend.
answer: What the hell are you talking about?

question: It's okay. I know he left me to be with you and I accept that.
answer: I don't know who you've been talking to, but it's safe to say that you're fucking trippin'.

question: It's fine really. It's going to take a while for me to get over it, but I'll be okay.
answer: Oh fuckin' Lord. This is disgusting.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Pull it together. This is how you run around all the time? Have some self-respect. No wonder your man left you. Who the hell would want to be around this shit all day?

question: Jesus teaches us to forgive. And I forgive you for what you did to me when you stole my boyfriend. Plus, I feel pretty confident that you'll end up burning in hell because of the various evil ways you live your life and that brings me some satisfaction. But I just want to tell you that Ronnie is a good person. He does a lot of stupid stuff, but really, he wants to do good for the world. I want you to know that if you hurt him and ruin his heart, I will personally come down here and kick the ever living shit out of you.
answer: You better fuckin' run, bitch! I'm just kidding.

question: Ronnie, I've been expecting you.
answer: You have?

question: Oh yeah, I heard about last night. Brandi is quite the woman. Congratulations, my friend. Or should I say, welcome to the club?
answer: What color of roses do the women like anyway?

question: Well, it depends on what you are trying to say. The white roses symbolize innocence and purity.
answer: Yeah, we're way past the color white if you know what I mean. What about the yellow ones?

question: Joy, happiness, appreciation.
answer: I don't even know what to make of that.

question: The pink rose means thank you.
answer: Next.

question: The red rose is the most powerful. It symbolizes love.
answer: Why didn't you just say that? I'm a busy man here.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Forget it. Give me a big bag of the red ones.

question: Um, can I ask a question?
answer: Go ahead.

question: Do you really like Brandi?
answer: I've only been on one date with her, but I could see myself being with her for all of eternity.

question: Well, in that case, the greatest symbol of love is just a single red rose.
answer: Seems like a big bag of roses would be more love than just one, but I guess you're the expert. Gimme one.

question: Brandi?
answer: What are you doing here?

question: I came here to see you. And to present you with this single red rose. It symbolizes 'love.'
answer: Ronnie, that's really... uncalled for.

question: Well, after last night, I just wanted you to know that it wasn't just some fling to me. It meant something special and I felt it deep in my soul.
answer: Oh, like you've never been drunk, Bruce! Ronnie, look. I got to be honest with you. I barely remember last night.

question: I remember it for the both of us.
answer: Okay, see here's the thing. I don't know how to say this, so I'm just gonna come on out with it. Ronnie, I could never date you seriously. I mean, you're a security guard.

question: I'm the head of Mall Security.
answer: Exactly. The point is, I don't really see myself being with that. Like ever. You know what I mean?

question: Brandi, I know exactly what you mean. And I just want to thank you for being honest. You're telling me I'm not living up to my full potential in life. It's funny, because I've been feeling like this for quite some time. I guess I just needed that extra little push to get me over this hurdle I've been stuck on. How can you be with a man who isn't living the life he was meant to?
answer: Yeah, something like that. And just you know, you're a security guard at the mall and it's like, come on, you know?

question: I don't like it, Brandi, but I do understand. I promise you this. Next time you see me, I will be wearing a uniform that will make you proud. I will be the man that you will be honored to call your life's love.
answer: Don't bet on it.

question: I will though. I'll bet everything I have on you. Now I ask you for one favor. Although I am unworthy, will you accept this rose from me anyway?
answer: I can't do that. And tell your girlfriend to stop coming by my work and threatening me and shit.

question: I'm here to become a police officer. I have a GED. You bet your ass I am. That sounds fun. Sign me up. It's like it was meant to be. You behind the wheel. Me riding shotgun. Two brothers of the badge unite to form the ultimate crime-stopping combo. I'm psyched to be here, Harrison. Thank you for the opportunity.
answer: You requested to ride along with me.

question: I know. You want to know the truth. It's because I respect you. See, when we're at the mall, it's obviously my turf. Sure, I break your balls about being a rookie, but out here in the streets, I'm the rookie. I'm here to learn. Teach me.
answer: Why do you want to become a Cop?

question: I've wanted to be a Police officer all my life. Don't get me wrong, I love keeping the mall safe, but you guys are the ones that really enforce justice and protect, not just our mall, but our whole community. I don't tell the guys on my squad this, but the Security Guard job was just temporary.
answer: Well, just pay attention tonight and make sure you stay out of the way.

question: Right, we're not back at the station anymore so we can cut the charade.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Well, I know that policy demands I stay out of the way, but between you and me, I just want you to know that if anything pops off tonight, I'm going to jump right in there and take 'em down with you.
answer: No, no. Ronnie, policy says you have to stay in the car.

question: I get you. You have to say this in order to keep you safe 'legally' speaking. I should probably follow along too. 'I swear I won't get out of the car and fight justice tonight.'
answer: Ronnie, you really can't.

question: I know.
answer: I'm glad we understand each other.

question: Yeah, so then I basically saw his ass trying to circumvent around the ped exit and slip through the employ exit. Not allowed. The two ped exits are to be used only --
answer: You see that corner there, Ronnie?

question: Yeah, I see it.
answer: That corner used to be the worst corner in this whole town. It was riddled with drugs, prostitution, and gang violence. It was nicknamed 'The Crossroads.'

question: Shit, I've heard of that.
answer: That's right, but myself and the other officers worked on cleaning it up for years so that the good folks of this neighborhood wouldn't have to worry about being safe. Yes, sir, that corner is a testament to the fine police work of our force.

question: I don't know. It looks pretty shitty to me.
answer: Well, it's a low income area, Ronnie. You're being kind of prejudiced.

question: Oh, yeah, I can see that it's basically a fine neighborhood.
answer: That's right, but it hasn't been easy. We still patrol this area every night just to keep our presence up.

question: I use that same technique at the mall.
answer: I'm sure. I usually do the foot patrols myself, but because I like you, I'm going to let you do it tonight.

question: Really?
answer: Yeah, really. But I told you about department policy, so I'm going to need you to keep quiet about this one.

question: You can count on me. Thank you for the honor.
answer: Of course, Ronnie. I just really believe in you.

question: I won't let you down. Where are you going?! Hey, no horse play. You guys get on home. No, I don't want any crack. In fact, I didn't want to do this, but you leave me no choice in the matter. I'm placing you under citizen's arrest. I place you under citizen's arrest for the crime of selling a Schedule 1 Narcotic. You have the right to remain silent... ... If you cannot afford an attorney, one will be appointed to you. Now I guess we just wait here for my ride to come back. Who, this little guy right here? Well, I hate to be the one to tell you this, but it appears that your little brother has tried to sell me illegal drugs. I know it's hard for you to hear that. Is that so? Well then, it looks like you got one less employee because I'm taking little brother down. I'll die right here before I let crime prevail. Free to go, little brother. My mistake completely. Good luck with the crack. Alright, so I guess I'll be seeing you folks. Oh, no. That's really not necessary, Tone. Oh, Jesus, I don't want to die. Don't let me die, don't do it! No, please! I'm sorry!
answer: Trust me, you would have done the same thing. This guy is without a doubt the biggest fucking idiot I have ever met. Good! Fuck him, I hope he does get killed. Ronnie, what are you doing here?

question: I know what you did!
answer: Ronnie, look, I didn't do anything --

question: You're not going to talk your way out of this one. You set me up!
answer: Ronnie, look --

question: Don't try to deny it! You set me up and that's all there is to it.
answer: Ronnie, I --

question: And I just want to thank you for it.
answer: Thank me? Why?

question: Because I'm proud to report that I passed the test. I know you wanted to see if I had the chops to cut it on the police force and I'm glad to say that I passed. I knew I would get initiated some time, but I didn't think it would be so soon. Thank you, Detective Harrison. Thank you for believing in me.
answer: Ronnie, I don't know what to say.

question: Come in.
answer: Good morning, Mark.

question: Is it, Ronnie? I mean, the mall is getting butchered in the press. Somebody who works here is ripping the place off. The cops don't have any leads. I'm getting shit from the owner of the mall. Sales are down. I mean, what's so good about this morning?
answer: I feel your pain, Mark. Quite frankly, there's two things happening. One, I'm lacking a sufficient firearm. And two, we're understaffed. That's why I come to you this morning with a plan. Come on in, Charles.

question: Who is this?
answer: This is Charles, sir.

question: Be careful, guys. Nice and slow.
answer: That's not bad, but you need to learn to speak in a more authoritative voice. Watch this. Slow it down! Slow it down! You've already received one verbal, don't make me issue a second! See, you can't be intimidated. You have to make them respect you.

question: Ronnie, you know I really want to thank you for the job. You're a man of your word.
answer: No problem, my young student. So, I got something to tell you. Keep this between us until it's official, but I don't think I'm going to be here for much longer.

question: You're quitting? But you love this job.
answer: I do love it, but it looks like someone is going to be joining the police force.

question: The real police?
answer: They're calling me up. It's basically a done deal. Just a little red tape is the only thing keeping me from carrying a gun.

question: I didn't even know you wanted to become a Cop.
answer: It's always been my job. The Mall thing is great training, but it has its limitations. Some stars are just meant to shine brighter than others.

question: Congrats, brother.
answer: HEY, SLOW IT DOWN, LADY! Nell?

question: HEY, SLOW IT DOWN, LADY! Nell?
answer: Hey, Ronnie.

question: What are you doing?
answer: Nothing, just getting in shape.

question: Well, that's okay, I guess. Just watch your speed, okay?
answer: Isn't that your girlfriend?

question: Ex.
answer: She looked good.

question: You think so?
answer: She looks a lot better.

question: Yeah.
answer: Okay, Ronnie, today I'll be giving you a psychiatric evaluation to determine if you're competent to enter into the Police Academy. It's really just a formality. Don't want any serial killers working for us, now do we?

question: No, ma'am, we don't.
answer: Okay, Ronnie, so let's start with your background. Where are you from?

question: Born and raised right here.
answer: Local boy. Okay, and, Ronnie, have you ever been convicted of any crimes?

question: No, ma'am. My record is totally clean.
answer: Do you now take any illegal drugs or have you taken any in the past?

question: No, ma'am. I believe drugs are the path to self-destruction and should be purged from the face of the earth with ruthless vengeance.
answer: Any prescription medications?

question: Yes, for my nerves. A man in my line of work has a lot of stress to deal with. If you've seen the bloodshed I've seen, you'd be on the meds too. I -- Where are you going with this?
answer: Are you presently or have you ever been affiliated with the Communist Party?

question: I can't believe you'd even ask me that.
answer: Have you ever been in the military?

question: Yes.
answer: What branch of the military were you in?

question: The kind of branch that doesn't exist on paper.
answer: Okay, here's a real world scenario. You have a gun --

question: Finally.
answer: That wasn't really the question, never mind, I think I got that one. Um... here's one. Do you feel like you would work well on a team?

question: Would I? Yes. Would I be more useful working alone, I would say definitely. I see myself more like a Rambo kind of guy. A man who rolls solo. Taking care of business on his own terms. Kind of like a Superhero or something.
answer: Why do you want to become a cop?

question: I want to become a cop to help people. The world is a scary place with lots of evil everywhere. See, I have this vision of evil trying to get at the world from every angle and there I stand at the top of it all with my gun, just kind of blowing it away. Just me and my weapons, cleaning up this whole town. I know I could do some good if I was just given a chance and everybody would be a lot better off.
answer: Uh-huh. So, what do you feel is the greatest danger facing a police officer today?

question: Maybe Russian gang activity, but you know what? I think I'm gonna have to go with evil on that one too.
answer: Okay, I think we're good here. It's been a pleasure, Ronnie.

question: Thank you, ma'am. I'm telling you, Mom, this police thing could be good for both of us. Not just the fact that I'll be making the streets safer for you, but they have health insurance and a pension plan so I don't have to worry about your medical bills as much.
answer: I don't care about that bullshit. All I need is a little nip of this good shit right here and I'm ready to walk through the pearly gates.

question: Mom, I know, but maybe you should stop drinking so much. You're getting up there and you know what the doctor said about your liver.
answer: I don't tell you how to party, don't tell me how to live my life. I've taken care of you since you were born.

question: I just worry about you is all.
answer: Ronnie, don't get your hopes up about this police thing.

question: Why would you say that?
answer: You know why. I just don't want to see you get hurt. It's my job to protect you from the bullshit.

question: Mom, I appreciate it, but I'm going to make it as a police officer. I'm tired of coming in second all the time. Everybody in life gets to go for their goals, why should I be any different?
answer: I know. Just be careful is all. You've got a good heart and I don't want to see it broken.

question: Okay, Mom. I hear you.
answer: And, Ronnie, one more thing.

question: What's that, Mom? Mom! That's gross!
answer: That's right! Now you got to smell it!

question: Mom. Ronnie Barnhardt reporting for duty.
answer: I can see that. Listen, I don't really know how to say this, but we're not going to be able to let you join the academy.

question: What?! Why not?
answer: It seems you had a little trouble passing the minimum requirements.

question: Did I fail one of the tests?
answer: Well, yes, actually, you failed the psychological exam.

question: No!
answer: It says... That Ronnie Barnhardt shows warning signs of delusion and allowing him to join the force puts his life and the lives of others in jeopardy.

question: Detective Harrison, you've got to believe me. I'm completely sound. This has got to be a mistake.
answer: Ronnie, I personally did your background check and this is the fifth time you've been turned down for the police academy.

question: You guys keep records on that?
answer: We sure do. Look, I tried to talk to them, but there's no way they're gonna let you in. I'm sorry, but your dreams of becoming a Police Officer just aren't going to happen.

question: I understand. Thanks for believing in me, Detective. And just for the record, I'm not crazy.
answer: Take care, Ronnie.

question: Hey, Nell.
answer: Hey, Ronnie. How's it going?

question: Can I talk to you for a second?
answer: What is it?

question: I tried to get into the police academy again and the same thing happened.
answer: Oh, Ronnie, I'm sorry.

question: Why does this keep happening to me, Nell?
answer: I don't know, Ronnie. Maybe it's just not meant to be. Are you okay?

question: No. Are you going home? I mean, do you want to go somewhere and talk or something?
answer: Ronnie, I can't.

question: Why not?
answer: I've got plans.

question: What plans?
answer: Look at this sorry piece of shit.

question: What the fuck do you want?
answer: I don't want anything from you. How you doing, sweetness? You look beautiful tonight.

question: What the fuck is going on?
answer: You ready to go? We got reservations at 9:00.

question: What are you doing, Ronnie?
answer: I'm just taking a break. What do you want, Stevie? I don't have time to fuck around with you today.

question: I got something.
answer: What the fuck is this? This thing gets grosser and grosser all the time. Well, thanks for the clue. Maybe I can use this to identify the freak. You can skate all you want around here.

question: What's wrong with you, Ronnie?
answer: What do you mean?

question: I don't know. You just seem kind of sad.
answer: Nah, man, I'm fine. I mean, I'm catchin' perverts and protecting this mall and just you know, really livin' the dream.

question: That's cool. Look, man, you want to get high?
answer: No, I don't want to get high.

question: That's cool.
answer: And by the way, if I see you getting high, I will call the police and have your criminal ass arrested. Don't you fuckin' ever mistake my kindness for weakness. I hate drugs and I hate you too.

question: Shit!
answer: That motherfucker is crazy.

question: Well, you're the fucking cop. Do something.
answer: You're right. Okay, here it goes.

question: What the fuck are you doing?! Ronnie, it's me! Don't do anything crazy.
answer: Get back inside, Brandi. This isn't about you... you... you slut!

question: Fuck off, Ronnie.
answer: How can you just stand there after you ruined my life and act like nothing happened?!

question: Drop the flashlight, Ronnie.
answer: You're pretty tough with that gun.

question: Ronnie, I know you've had a hard time --
answer: You were supposed to be my friend!

question: So you're gonna kill Brandi?
answer: I was just trying to scare her.

question: That guy is a nut job.
answer: Tell me about it.

question: So you slept with him?
answer: I was drunk okay. You gonna make a big deal out of it.

question: No, I guess not.
answer: Fine.

question: I'm disbanding the task force.
answer: Hey, Ronnie, that's crazy talk. Are you cool?

question: No, I'm not cool, Charles. In fact, shit is seriously fucked up. I've got to protect the whole mall by myself. Now, I got you this fucking job, when are you going to stop being a little baby and do something for a change.
answer: I'm gonna go check the parking lot.

question: I'm sorry, Charles! I didn't mean it, buddy! You know, Dennis, for the longest time I made this job my whole life. I looked at this mall as a kingdom and I looked at Mark as the King. I thought of myself as the first Knight and the customers, well, they were the peasants. I lived by an old code where one was bound by duty and honor. But now I don't know if I believe in that code anymore. I've lost my way. Now I just feel like it's one big kingdom of shit. Right now, I got half a mind just to let this whole place burn. Burn it to the fucking ground!
answer: I've been waiting on you to get on my page this whole time. You look at this mall as a Kingdom?! Shit! I look at this place like a motherfucking jail sentence. You put on that uniform every morning, but what are you really protecting? Commerce and corporations and money. Well I say, fuck that! I'm a fucking outlaw and I'm going to live that until the day I die. Now, I can show you the way, but you've got to be willing to accept it. So I'm gonna ask you now, Ronnie. Are you ready for a trip to the other side?

question: You're goddamn right I'm ready.
answer: Alright then. Let's party. So, yeah, usually I take a joint straight to the head before I start work in this motherfucker, but on really stressful days, I like to get drunk too.

question: Dennis, I got to thank you for today. Man, I was so down, but you taught me that I don't need to take things so seriously here. We have a pointless existence. Who gives a fuck?
answer: Don't mention it, homey. I'm just glad I got me a partner in crime.

question: A partner. I like that. You know, I've never really had a friend before, but I think that this could be the beginning of a real good thing.
answer: You ain't even seen the best part. After everybody leaves, I rob the shit out of this place.

question: What do you mean?
answer: I steal shit!

question: You're the one who's been robbing the mall?
answer: Hell yeah! Who'd you think it was?!

question: I can't believe this. Right in front of my goddamn face this whole time!
answer: This probably will look good with my complexion.

question: Dennis, I can't take part in this.
answer: Ronnie, I thought you were down?! What the fuck?! Here I am opening up myself to you and you're just gonna stick it to me like this. What the fuck has this place ever done for you? Don't you know that people see us as jokes?! A useless tool that's left in the shed. Well that's not me. Not now, not ever. I told you, I'm an outlaw.

question: I can't let you rob the mall.
answer: What the fuck you mean you can't let me?

question: Come on, Dennis. We're best friends, so just put that stuff back and let's go get a beer.
answer: Alright, Ronnie, you're right. I don't really know what I was thinking. Robbing the mall? Let's just go get that beer.

question: Good, man. That makes me feel better.
answer: See ya in Mexico, bitch.

question: Ramon, get your ass over here! Go get my spare keys out of the office. Ramon! Goddamn it get back here! Go get my goddamn keys.
answer: How fucking stupid do you have to be?! I mean Dennis. What the fuck, Ronnie? How could you not have known it was Dennis? Then, how the fuck could you be so stupid as to let him get away. OBSERVE AND REPORT. Those are the only two things you have to do and you can't do those worth a shit.

question: Can I speak now?
answer: Go ahead.

question: Are you sure?
answer: Just start talking, Ronnie!

question: It seems only natural that 'some people' would want to blame me and truth be told I do put a lot of that blame on myself. But some people might say that the cops are to blame for not catching them. Some people might say that the reason this happened was the undeniable fact that I was under- equipped and quite frankly, lacking a sufficient firearm. But not me. I carry this loss alone deep inside my heart.
answer: Good. Because you're fired. I'm serious, Ronnie. I've always liked you, but there's just no excuse for this. Somebody is going down and I'll be damned if it's going to be me. Now, don't make a big thing out of this. Just pack your shit and get out by the end of the day.

question: Wait a minute. I thought I could trust you, Mark, and now you're telling me that you're going to be the one to put the knife in my back. Fair weather friend you are.
answer: I'm not your friend, I'm your boss.

question: You think you're so smart, Mark. You don't know everything. If you're firing me, then you can say goodbye to your entire Security staff. Because there is no fucking way my team is going to work here if you fire me. Isn't that right, Charles?
answer: Ronnie, I got to talk to you about this. Mark asked me down here to escort you out.

question: And you told him to fuck off, right? Charles? Right?
answer: What the fuck do you want from me, Ronnie?

question: This isn't happening! Everybody is fucking me over?! I hate you all.
answer: I'm sorry, Ronnie, but it's time to go.

question: Wait a minute. I'll work for free, Mark.
answer: No, Ronnie.

question: I'll pay you.
answer: Nope.

question: I love you.
answer: Ronnie, Jesus have a little self- respect.

question: You don't love me, Mark?
answer: Ronnie, it's over.

question: Hey, Charles. Mark asked you down here in case I got out of hand? Well, get ready to earn your money.
answer: Stop him!

question: What's on the agenda for today?
answer: I guess maybe look for a job or something.

question: Well, I know you're sad about it, but try to look on the bright side.
answer: There is no bright side. My life is over.

question: Ronnie, you may not be smart or handsome, but you've got dreams inside of you and dreams make you special. No matter what this world tries to throw at you, they can never take those dreams away.
answer: What the fuck are you talking about, Mom?

question: I don't know. I'm drunk. I just know that mothers are supposed to talk like that to their children when they're sad, so I tried. What do you want from me?
answer: Nothing. That's exactly what you're supposed to do. I just blew my life. I tried to be a big shot, a hero and a stupid cop. I wanted to be recognized for being great. I should have just been happy where I was at. I didn't do my duty.

question: Ronnie, the other night when I soiled my pants right before I puked myself, I was thinking about how you would come home and find me and clean me up. I knew you would be there to find me and take care of me, so I was able to pass out on the floor and not worry. If there's one thing you know about, it's duty.
answer: I do it because I love you.

question: I know and I love you too, Ronnie. I haven't always been easy to deal with and most people would have thrown me away a long time ago. Just like your father did. But not you, Ronnie. Look, whiskey was always the way I dealt with being a single mother, but as I get older, I know that I can't keep doing this. I've got everything I need with you. So I want you to know that I'm ready to make a change. Your life needs to get easier and you don't need to take care of old Mom anymore.
answer: Are you going to quit drinking?

question: I'm switching to beer. I can pound those all day and still keep my shit together. I'm doing it for you.
answer: I'm so proud of you, Mom.

question: What's up, Ronnie? How you doing?
answer: I've been better. You?

question: I'm holding it down in here.
answer: Yeah, I heard they finally caught up with you.

question: I know. I should have hit Mexico, but, you know, I got stoned and just kind of kicked with this girl in Kannapolis for a while.
answer: You know they fired me when they found out you were the one who robbed the mall.

question: Shit, dog. Sorry about that.
answer: It's cool, but I need to know why you did it.

question: I told you. I'm an outlaw.
answer: Come on, Dennis.

question: Man, you want to know the real reason?
answer: Yeah.

question: Alright, I'll tell you. Man, that gig was one of the best jobs I ever had. I got to wear a uniform, I could smoke weed whenever I wanted. For once in my life, I felt like I was actually somebody. I know most people don't think it's shit, but I really loved it. Then, all of a sudden, I find out that your ass got promoted over me. After all I put into it, you're the one that makes it to Head of Mall Security. You know what it's like to get passed over, Ronnie? So I got pissed off. I started robbing the joint as a way to get at them for what they did to me. But you know what, Ronnie?
answer: What's that?

question: You ever love a girl so much that you can't break up with her, so the only thing you can do when she pisses you off is smack her in the goddamn face?
answer: No, Dennis, I haven't.

question: Well, I have. And that's pretty much how I felt about the job.
answer: Thanks for talking to me, Dennis.

question: Well, it's the least I could do after knocking you out and all. Hey, Ronnie.
answer: Yeah, Dennis.

question: Bail me out of here, old friend.
answer: I can't do it, Dennis. You're now a criminal who stopped caring, but my crime is that I care too much.

question: Ronnie, what are you doing back here?
answer: I just came to talk to Nell. Don't get your panties in a wad, I'm just here as any normal patron.

question: Ronnie, dude, I've been all fucked up in the head. I feel like shit about what happened. I mean, here I am, just looking to shuck responsibility and I ended up hurting you in the process. Look, I should have been honest with you. I don't give two shits about this stupid job. But you do.
answer: It's okay, Charles.

question: I've decided I'm going back to college. Getting stoned and studying beats this any day. I realize that now. I realize that there aren't any jobs where you can avoid hard choices. Anyway, take as long as you want at the mall. I'll keep Mark off your back.
answer: Thanks, Charles.

question: Ronnie, what are you doing here?
answer: I got something I want to say.

question: I don't think we should be talking.
answer: I'll be quick. Nell, this is the only job I was ever any good at. I'm not a crime solver or right hand of the law. I'm just a dumb guy in a uniform who can't even become a real policeman. Somewhere along the way I started to think I was something special, someone whose shit didn't stink, someone who deserved to date out of my league. You know, I've learned. My shit does stink. It smells horrible. And you're also out of my league, but for some reason, you like the smell of my shit. I guess what I'm saying is... If you give me another chance, I'll spend the rest of my life making it up to you. And you can call me sweetie in front of people and I'll like it. Son of a bitch!!!

question: Oh, my God!
answer: Are you alright?

question: I'm fine.
answer: Shit, we should call somebody.

question: Ronnie.
answer: Yeah?

question: Okay, show's over. Enjoy your shopping experience at Carolina Mall. Jesus. Charles!
answer: What is it?

question: Call the police. And go get Ronnie.
answer: He's trying to help.

question: Just do what I ask you.
answer: Hey, Ronnie!

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: Good job, Ronnie.

question: I don't love you!
answer: I don't love you either.

question: Fine. I caught the Pervert.
answer: I see that. Well, you better turn him over to me and I'll take him inside and book him.

question: Since you're a real Cop, right?
answer: Hey, Ronnie, you may not be an officer of the law, but you're the law's right hand. Good job.
